newsitem.title: UNITED NATIONS: U.N. oil deal monitors put off trip to Iraq.
newsitem.headline: U.N. oil deal monitors put off trip to Iraq.

text.p: An advance team of three inspectors from a Dutch firm has postponed a visit to Iraq because of the unstable situation in the country's northern regions, diplomats said on Tuesday.
The inspectors were pulled out of Iraq in September when fighting flared in the northern Kurdish provinces and the United Nations delayed implementing an oil-for-food plan.
Diplomats said the oil monitors had been scheduled to go back this week to perform preliminary inspections ahead of a possible implementation of the plan.

But their visit was further delayed further because of the situation in the north, where the United States is currently trying to implement a ceasefire between two Kurdish factions, the diplomats said.

The oil-for-food deal allows Iraq to sell $2 billion of oil over six months, on a renewable basis, to buy food, medicine and other necessities to help offset the effect on ordinary Iraqis of sanctions imposed after Iraq's August 1990 invasion of Kuwait.

In other developments, Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali said the United Nations was still trying to "overcome all the difficulties because I believe it is a must to implement 986," a reference to the Security Council resolution that sets out the plan.
"The fact that there is a war going on has complicated our situation on the ground," he added.
He said he was currently meeting with Gualtiero Fulcheri, the senior U.N. representative in Baghdad, who arrived in New York two days ago.
